channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: How 2 Flights to Europe May Have Spurred Spread of New Variant
item.description: A confounding array of Covid rules and lax enforcement of mask wearing may have sent on infected passengers on two KLM flights from South Africa to “who knows where.”
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Flight restrictions began in South Africa’s O.R. Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg last week.

item.title: Omicron Variant, in 20 Nations, Spread Earlier Than Was Known
item.description: With evidence growing that a worrisome new coronavirus variant is highly contagious, health officials issued warnings that vulnerable people should not travel.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A Covid vaccination in Johannesburg, South Africa, on Tuesday.

item.title: Josephine Baker Inducted Into French Panthéon
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron hailed the American-born dancer and French resistance fighter as a symbol of unity in a time of sharp division.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The ceremony for Josephine Baker in Paris on Tuesday.

item.title: ‘Our Money Has No Value’: Frustration Rises in Turkey at Lira Crisis
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s insistence on directing monetary policy and sticking with low interest rates is draining confidence, economists say.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: A protest in Istanbul last week against worsening economic conditions.

item.title: Covid Live Updates: Travelers to U.S. may face tougher coronavirus testing
item.description: A judge blocked a vaccine mandate for U.S. health workers. Merck’s Covid pill recommended for high-risk adults by F.D.A. panel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers from South Africa are tested for the Coronavirus Omicron variant upon arrival in a specially designed test lane at the Schiphol airport, The Netherlands, on Tuesday.

item.title: Report: Rampant Sexual Harassment in Australia’s Parliament
item.description: A sweeping report lays out a cloistered, alcohol-fueled environment where powerful men violated boundaries unchecked.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A report has found that sexual harassment is rife in Australia’s Parliament, making it a hostile workplace for many employees, especially young female staffers.

item.title: Amid Variant Fears, U.K. Discovers Limits to Its Virus Strategy
item.description: Britain’s approach to coronavirus-related restrictions has been looser than other European countries, but the Omicron variant has spurred swift action on mitigation measures.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Megan Specia
item.media:description: Commuters at London Bridge station on Tuesday as Britain stepped up its attempts to ward off the Omicron variant.

item.title: Myanmar Delays 1st Verdict in Aung San Suu Kyi Trial
item.description: The ousted civilian leader is facing a series of rulings that could keep her locked up for the rest of her life.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee

item.title: ISIS Fighter Convicted in Death of Enslaved 5-Year-Old Girl
item.description: In a trial held in Germany, the man was sentenced to life in prison for the death of the Yazidi girl, whom he allowed to die of thirst in Falluja, Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Taha Al-J., covering his face with a folder, speaking with his lawyers before he was convicted in the court in Frankfurt on Tuesday.

item.title: Éric Zemmour, Far-Right Pundit, Makes French Presidential Run Official
item.description: After months of speculation, Mr. Zemmour, an anti-immigration writer and right-wing television star, said he was running in the presidential elections next year to “save” France.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Éric Zemmour, center, in Marseille on Saturday. His previously undeclared campaign for France’s presidency has hit several setbacks in recent days.

item.title: China’s Silence on Peng Shuai Shows Limits of Beijing’s Propaganda
item.description: Officials have struggled to respond to a sexual assault allegation that hits at the heights of its buttoned-up political system.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Within China, the tennis star Peng Shuai’s #MeToo allegations have been systematically purged from social media.

item.title: Barbados Drops the Queen and Becomes a Republic
item.description: The island nation swore in its first president, ending nearly 400 years of British rule. Prince Charles and Rihanna were on hand to witness the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Rihanna, center, was declared a “national hero” during the ceremony.

item.title: After the Floods, British Columbia Picks Up the Pieces
item.description: Washed-out roads and destroyed bridges are just some of the devastation afflicting residents of the western province and could signal what climate change will bring in the future.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: A truck damaged in recent flooding last week in Merritt, British Columbia.

item.title: Dozens of Former Afghan Security Forces Dead or Missing Under Taliban, Report Says
item.description: More than 100 former members of the military and police have been killed or forcibly disappeared by the Taliban since the group came into power, according to an investigation by Human Rights Watch.
item.dc:creator: Sharif Hassan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Taliban patrolling Jalalabad last month.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks Vaccine Mandate for Health Workers
item.description: The ruling is a setback for the administration’s effort to require vaccination for hospital and nursing home workers, which had been set to start next week.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah and Reed Abelson
item.media:description: Protesters rally against vaccine mandates in New York City.

item.title: South African Company Nears License to Sell J. & J. Covid Shot Across Africa
item.description: The new agreement makes Aspen Pharmacare the first African company to market a Covid vaccine on the continent. But it stops short of allowing Aspen to make the ingredients in the vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Aspen Pharmacare bottled the vaccine under a previous agreement, but a new deal would allow the company to market and distribute the drug as well.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The Omicron variant was in Europe at least a week ago.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: A shopping area in Amsterdam was mostly empty on Monday after a coronavirus lockdown went into effect to counteract rising infections and hospital admissions.

item.title: How do you say ‘Omicron’?
item.description: Unlike Alpha, Beta and Delta, the name of the latest known variant is not as straightforward, with some English speakers offering up diverse pronunciations.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser

item.title: England tightens restrictions as more Omicron cases found.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Britain returned to mask mandates on Tuesday, including requiring them for all public transit riders.

item.title: What We Know About the New Covid Variant, Omicron
item.description: Intense research into the new coronavirus variant first identified in southern Africa has just begun. World leaders have urged people not to panic — and to get vaccinated, if they can.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:description: A woman receiving a Covid shot vaccine at a center in Soweto, South Africa.

item.title: Nepal’s embattled chief justice tests positive for the virus, amid broad political disarray.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: Protesters in Kathmandu, Nepal, last week demanded the resignation of Cholendra Shumsher Rana as chief justice of Nepal’s Supreme Court over corruption accusations.

item.title: Greece to Fine Older Residents Who Don't Get Vaccinated
item.description: It is the latest European nation to announce restrictions on the unvaccinated, as the country tries to stem a surge.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Monks waited to get a Covid-19 vaccine on Mount Athos, Greece, this month.

item.title: Covax sets aside vaccine doses for North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Kim Won Jin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pedestrians in Pyongyang, North Korea, this month.

item.title: Fighting Racism, Quietly
item.description: The Ahmaud Arbery trial offers lessons for American politics.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for Ahmaud Arbery.

item.title: Counterfeit Covid Masks Are Still Sold Everywhere
item.description: Rising Covid cases have spurred a return to mask-wearing in the U.S. and overseas, at a time when flawed KN95s from China continue to dominate e-commerce sites.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aaron Collins, a mechanical engineer in Minneapolis, tested the effectiveness of various masks, both counterfeit and genuine, in the makeshift lab he set up in his bathroom.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A familiar, frantic response.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Berlin opened new vaccination centers in order to accommodate people seeking a booster shot.

item.title: In Latest Assault on Dissent, Egypt Convicts a Human Rights Activist
item.description: Hossam Bahgat avoided a prison term, receiving a relatively modest fine, in a verdict that appeared designed to intimidate dissidents without risking international opprobrium.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Hossam Bahgat outside a courtoom in Cairo in 2016. He was convicted on Monday of insulting a government authority.

item.title: With Scant Information on Omicron, Biden Turned to Travel Ban to Buy Time
item.description: “Here’s what it does: It gives us time,” President Biden said of the flight restrictions. He called the new variant a cause for concern, not panic.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Stolberg
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The sudden arrival of a new and potentially dangerous variant poses a challenge for President Biden, who was elected on a promise to bring the pandemic under control.

item.title: World Omicron Fight Hindered by Fragmented Response
item.description: Almost two years into the pandemic, finger-pointing, lack of coordination, sparse information and fear are once again influencing policy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: A ticket counter at the O.R. Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg on Monday.

item.title: Biden Military Review Leaves Troops Where They Are, for Now
item.description: The report sidesteps a decision on what to do about troop numbers in Somalia, after President Donald J. Trump’s decision to pull out last year.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden visited troops at Fort Bragg in Fayetteville, N.C., last week.

item.title: Catherine the Great Letter Up for Auction Shows Her Support for Inoculations
item.description: In a letter to be sold at auction this week, the Russian empress called for widespread access to a precursor of the smallpox vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: A portrait of Catherine the Great by Dmitry Levitsky will be auctioned alongside the letter in which she extols the virtues of variolation, an early inoculation process.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Confronting the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Staff members stand at the departure gate of Tokyo's Haneda international airport on Monday, as Japan announced plans to bar all new foreign travelers over the Omicron variant.

item.title: Iran Insists on Immediate Lifting of Sanctions as Nuclear Talks Resume
item.description: After five months, negotiations on restoring the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran resumed in Vienna, but with a harder line from the new Iranian government.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Iran’s chief nuclear negotiator, Ali Bagheri Kani, arrives for a meeting of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action in Vienna, Austria, on Monday.

item.title: South Africa Officials See 'No Red Flags Yet' on Omicron Variant
item.description: Officials said that while they need more data to be sure, existing treatments and precautions seem to be effective against the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Testing for the coronavirus in Johannesburg on Saturday.

item.title: Sweden Elects Its First Female Prime Minister, Again
item.description: The Swedish Parliament elected Magdalena Andersson as prime minister by a narrow margin. She was first elected last week, but her government soon collapsed over a budget dispute.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Christina Anderson
item.media:credit: Jonas Ekstromer/TT News. via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Magdalena Andersson in Stockholm on Monday after she became Sweden’s prime minister.

item.title: Xiomara Castro Vows New Era for Honduras but Is Tied to Past
item.description: Xiomara Castro, headed toward becoming her country’s next president, promises to expunge its legacy of corruption, but change may be tempered by her establishment ties and conservative opposition.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Joan Suazo
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Xiomara Castro during her presidential election campaign in Honduras this month.

item.title: UK Announces Omicron Cases and Extends Boosters to All Adults
item.description: The British government was widely criticized for a sluggish response to the Delta variant, and its reaction to Omicron came markedly quicker.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Commuters in London on Monday. The government will mandate masks on public transportation and in stores.

item.title: Dutch Police Arrest a Couple Who Fled Quarantine and Boarded a Plane.
item.description: One of the pair tested positive for the coronavirus after they arrived on a flight from South Africa. They were quarantined at a hotel.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The hotel in the Netherlands where some passengers who arrived on flights from South Africa are in quarantine after testing positive for the coronavirus.

item.title: Czech President Appoints Prime Minister From Inside a Cube
item.description: President Milos Zeman tested positive for the coronavirus on Thursday and went into isolation, delaying the ceremony for three days.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Czech President Milos Zeman, right, separated with a transparent wall after testing positive for the coronavirus, appoints Petr Fiala as Czech Prime Minister at the Lany Manor house, near Prague, Czech Republic on Sunday.

item.title: Scotland finds 6 cases of Omicron, but no sign its spread is ‘sustained.’
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s first minister, described the emergence of Omicron as the “most challenging development of the pandemic for quite some time.”

item.title: Portugal Detects 13 Omicron Cases Tied to Belenenses Soccer Team
item.description: The team, Belenenses, took part in a game that had to be abandoned after a Covid outbreak reduced the number of eligible players. One infected player had recently returned from South Africa.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: A soccer game in Portugal between Belenenses and Benfica over the weekend was abandoned after a virus outbreak. It was later revealed that some of those cases were of the Omicron variant.

item.title: A ‘Simpsons’ Episode Lampooned Chinese Censorship. In Hong Kong, It Vanished.
item.description: The episode mocked both Mao Zedong and the government’s efforts to suppress memory of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: The Latest on Omicron
item.description: What should you assume about the new variant?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A crowd in London this weekend.

item.title: As World Shuts Borders to Stop Omicron, Japan Offers a Cautionary Tale
item.description: Japan, which has been very cautious throughout the pandemic, is again barring all nonresident foreigners. There is an economic and human cost.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Sensoji shrine in Tokyo, which has typically been a top destination for foreign tourists.

item.title: Hunt for the ‘Blood Diamond of Batteries’ Impedes Green Energy Push
item.description: Dangerous mining conditions plague Congo, home to the world’s largest supply of cobalt, a key ingredient in electric cars. A leadership battle threatens reforms.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey, Eric Lipton and Ashley Gilbertson
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The foreman of a mining crew that is digging for cobalt in Kasulo.

item.title: Meet the Beauty Queens of Al Dhafra
item.description: Camel beauty contests take center stage at a celebration of Bedouin culture, held annually in the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Kiki Streitberger
item.media:description: Pert ears? Check. Long droopy lips? Check. A nose ring? Check. Expressive eyes framed by upward curled eyelashes? Check.

item.title: Taliban and 9/11 Families Fight for Billions in Frozen Afghan Funds
item.description: The White House must figure out what to do with the Afghan central bank’s account at the Federal Reserve, now blocked under U.S. law.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid, announcing the new Taliban government of Afghanistan at a press conference in Kabul in September.

item.title: She Fled North Korea for Freedom. Then She Was Arrested.
item.description: The case of “Chrysanthemum” offers a rare look at the covert battle the rival Koreas are waging over North Korean defectors living in the South.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph of Song Chun-son, who is in prison on espionage charges, being displayed by her sister, Song Chun-nyo.

item.title: Climate Change Driving Some Albatrosses to ‘Divorce,’ Study Finds
item.description: Warming oceans are sending the monogamous sea birds farther afield to find food, putting stress on their breeding and prompting some to ditch their partners.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Martin Zwick/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A colony of black-browed albatrosses in the Falkland Islands. Albatrosses usually mate for life.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Omicron moves across the world.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Passengers wearing protective gear arrive at Incheon International Airport, in South Korea on Sunday.

item.title: A Woman is Charged With Arson in Queensland Quarantine Hotel Fire
item.description: A 31-year-old mother and her two children had arrived in Queensland a few days ago.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The Pacific Hotel in Cairns, Australia, caught fire Sunday morning. Its 163 occupants were evacuated safely.

item.title: Both parties claim victory as Honduras awaits election results.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Voters wait for their ballots at a polling station in Tegucigalpa.

item.title: Snowstorm Leaves Dozens Stranded for Days in a Remote U.K. Pub
item.description: A crowd had gathered on Friday night to listen to Noasis, an Oasis tribute band. On Monday, most of them were finally able to go home.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:description: Snow as high as three feet in some places blocked the exits of the Tan Hill Inn in northern England.

item.title: Will the Covid Vaccines Stop Omicron? Scientists Are Racing to Find Out.
item.description: A “Frankenstein mix” of mutations raises concerns, but the variant may remain vulnerable to current vaccines. If not, revisions will be necessary.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A woman received her second Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine dose from a health care worker in Katlehong, east of Johannesburg, in South Africa.
